quiz.title: Components and Props Quiz
quiz.description:
It's time to check your knowledge! Use this quiz to create a custom study guide. Note any answers that were marked incorrect, so you can study the relevant material and try this quiz again.

If you don't know the answer to a question, please do not guess. Instead, select "I don't know". It's OK not to know everything and to admit when we're unsure.

questions.question_text:
I want to render the Card component inside of my Container component. How would I properly export the Card component? Select all that apply.

function Card({ title, subtitle }) {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>{title}</h1>
      <p>{subtitle}</p>
    </div>
  );
}

answers.text: function Card({ title, subtitle }) { return ( div h1{title}/h1 p{subtitle}/p /div ); } export default Card;
answers.html:
function Card({ title, subtitle }) {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>{title}</h1>
      <p>{subtitle}</p>
    </div>
  );
}

export default Card;
answers.comments: Correct! We can use the export default keywords to export a variable, and import it with import.
answers.comments_html: Correct! We can use the export default keywords to export a variable, and import it with import.

answers.text: export default function Card({ title, subtitle }) { return ( div h1{title}/h1 p{subtitle}/p /div ); }
answers.html:
export default function Card({ title, subtitle }) {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>{title}</h1>
      <p>{subtitle}</p>
    </div>
  );
}
answers.comments: Correct! We can use the export default keywords to export a variable or function, and import it with import.
answers.comments_html: Correct! We can use the export default keywords to export a variable or function, and import it with import.

answers.text: function Card({ title, subtitle }) { return ( div h1{title}/h1 p{subtitle}/p /div ); } export cardComponent;
answers.html:
function Card({ title, subtitle }) {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>{title}</h1>
      <p>{subtitle}</p>
    </div>
  );
}
export cardComponent;
answers.comments: Not quite. Be sure you are exporting the correct variable!

answers.html: I don't know.

questions.question_text:
I want to render the Card component inside of my Container component. How would I properly import the Card component?

// src/Card.js
function Card({ title, subtitle }) {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>{title}</h1>
      <p>{subtitle}</p>
    </div>
  );
}

export default Card;

answers.html:
// src/App.js
import Card from "./Card";
answers.comments: Correct! When importing a default export, we use the default import syntax along with a relative path to the file where the export is declared.
answers.comments_html: Correct! When importing a default export, we use the default import syntax along with a relative path to the file where the export is declared.

answers.html:
// src/App.js
import { Card } from "./Card";
answers.comments: Not quite. The named import syntax (with curly parentheses) only works with named exports, not default exports.
answers.comments_html: Not quite. The named import syntax (with curly parentheses) only works with named exports, not default exports.

answers.html:
// src/App.js
import default Card from './Card'
answers.comments: Not quite. This syntax isn't valid: we don't use the default keyword with the import keyword, only with the export keyword.
answers.comments_html: Not quite. This syntax isn't valid: we don't use the default keyword with the import keyword, only with the export keyword.

answers.html: I don't know.

questions.question_text: Which of the following components are valid? Select all that apply.
questions.neutral_comments: Source/s:React Components BasicsProps Destructuring and Default Values
questions.neutral_comments_html:
Source/s:

  • React Components Basics
  • Props Destructuring and Default Values

answers.text: function Card() { return ( div h1React/h1 pComponent/p /div ); }
answers.html:
function Card() {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>React</h1>
      <p>Component</p>
    </div>
  );
}

answers.text: function Card({ title, subtitle }) { return ( div h1{title}/h1 p{subtitle}/p /div ); }
answers.html:
function Card({ title, subtitle }) {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>{title}</h1>
      <p>{subtitle}</p>
    </div>
  );
}

answers.text: function card() { return ( div h1React/h1 pComponent/p /div ); }
answers.html:
function card() {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>React</h1>
      <p>Component</p>
    </div>
  );
}
answers.comments: This isn't a valid component, since all React components must start with a capital letter. Since card is lowercase, it's not a valid component, because React would treat this as a DOM element rather than a function component when rendered: ReactDOM.render(card /, document.querySelector("#root")); // produces these DOM elements: // div id="root" // card/card // /div
answers.comments_html:
This isn't a valid component, since all React components must start with a capital letter. Since card is lowercase, it's not a valid component, because React would treat this as a DOM element rather than a function component when rendered:

ReactDOM.render(<card />, document.querySelector("#root"));
// produces these DOM elements:
// <div id="root">
//   <card></card>
// </div>

answers.html:
function Card() {
  <div>
    <h1>React</h1>
    <p>Component</p>
  </div>;
}
answers.comments: This is not a valid component because it doesn't return JSX. Functions defined with the function keyword must explicitly return using the return keyword.
answers.comments_html: This is not a valid component because it doesn't return JSX. Functions defined with the function keyword must explicitly return using the return keyword.

questions.question_text: A React component is a function that takes in [blank1] and returns [blank2].
questions.incorrect_comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: A React function component must start with a capital letter.

answers.comments: Correct! React differentiates between a component and a regular DOM element based on capitalization. For example, making an article component with a lowercase name wouldn't work: function article() { return ( div h1React/h1 pComponent/p /div ); } ReactDOM.render(article /, document.getElementById("root"));  Trying to render this component would result in React rendering an article HTML element instead of the article component. Using an uppercase name for the function fixes this problem: function Article() { return ( div h1React/h1 pComponent/p /div ); } ReactDOM.render(Article /, document.getElementById("root"));
answers.comments_html:
Correct! React differentiates between a component and a regular DOM element based on capitalization. For example, making an <article> component with a lowercase name wouldn't work:

function article() {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>React</h1>
      <p>Component</p>
    </div>
  );
}

ReactDOM.render(<article />, document.getElementById("root"));

Trying to render this component would result in React rendering an <article> HTML element instead of the <article> component.

Using an uppercase name for the function fixes this problem:

function Article() {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>React</h1>
      <p>Component</p>
    </div>
  );
}

ReactDOM.render(<Article />, document.getElementById("root"));

answers.comments: React differentiates between a component and a regular DOM element based on capitalization. For example, making an article component with a lowercase name wouldn't work: function article() { return ( div h1React/h1 pComponent/p /div ); } ReactDOM.render(article /, document.getElementById("root"));  Trying to render this component would result in React rendering an article HTML element instead of the article component. Using an uppercase name for the function fixes this problem: function Article() { return ( div h1React/h1 pComponent/p /div ); } ReactDOM.render(Article /, document.getElementById("root"));
answers.comments_html:
React differentiates between a component and a regular DOM element based on capitalization. For example, making an <article> component with a lowercase name wouldn't work:

function article() {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>React</h1>
      <p>Component</p>
    </div>
  );
}

ReactDOM.render(<article />, document.getElementById("root"));

Trying to render this component would result in React rendering an <article> HTML element instead of the <article> component.

Using an uppercase name for the function fixes this problem:

function Article() {
  return (
    <div>
      <h1>React</h1>
      <p>Component</p>
    </div>
  );
}

ReactDOM.render(<Article />, document.getElementById("root"));

questions.question_text:
Given the following code, what would appear in the console?

function Parent() {
  const header = "Hello";
  const contents = "World";

  return <Child title={header} body={contents} minutesToRead={10} />;
}

function Child(props) {
  console.log(props);
  // ... return JSX
}

answers.html:
{
  title: "Hello",
  body: "World",
  minutesToRead: 10
}
answers.comments: Correct! The props parameter in every component is an object of key/value pairs based on the attributes assigned by the parent component.
answers.comments_html: Correct! The props parameter in every component is an object of key/value pairs based on the attributes assigned by the parent component.

answers.html:
{
  header: "Hello",
  contents: "World",
  minutesToRead: 10
}
answers.comments: Not quite. The keys on the props object are based on the attributes assigned by the parent component, which in this case are title, body, and minutesToRead.
answers.comments_html: Not quite. The keys on the props object are based on the attributes assigned by the parent component, which in this case are title, body, and minutesToRead.

answers.html:
{
  title: "header",
  body: "contents",
  minutesToRead: 10
}
answers.comments: Not quite. The keys on this props object are correct, but the values are based on what data is held in each variable in the parent component, not the names of the variables.
answers.comments_html: Not quite. The keys on this props object are correct, but the values are based on what data is held in each variable in the parent component, not the names of the variables.

answers.html: I don't know.

questions.question_text: We use ______ to pass data into a component.
questions.incorrect_comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: What is a React component? Select all that apply.

answers.text: A function that takes in props and returns JSX.
A reusable function for creating UI elements.

answers.html: I don't know.

questions.question_text: When should you use the key prop?

answers.text: When rendering an array of components.
answers.comments: Correct! The key prop is a special prop that React uses to help optimize performance when rendering arrays of components.
answers.comments_html: Correct! The key prop is a special prop that React uses to help optimize performance when rendering arrays of components.

answers.comments: Not quite. The key prop is a special prop that React uses to help optimize performance when rendering arrays of components. React can render two sibling components just fine with no key prop provided: function Parent() { return ( div Sibling / Sibling / /div ); }
answers.comments_html:
Not quite. The key prop is a special prop that React uses to help optimize performance when rendering arrays of components. React can render two sibling components just fine with no key prop provided:

function Parent() {
  return (
    <div>
      <Sibling />
      <Sibling />
    </div>
  );
}

answers.text: Any time .map is used in a component.
answers.html: Any time .map is used in a component.
answers.comments: Not quite. The key prop is a special prop that React uses to help optimize performance when rendering arrays of components. While we often use the key prop when using .map to create an array of components, just using .map in a component isn't enough to indicate the need for the key prop.
answers.comments_html: Not quite. The key prop is a special prop that React uses to help optimize performance when rendering arrays of components. While we often use the key prop when using .map to create an array of components, just using .map in a component isn't enough to indicate the need for the key prop.

answers.html: I don't know.

questions.question_text: Which of the following are true of JSX? Select all that apply.

answers.text: JSX is an abstraction of the DOM.

answers.comments: While they may look similar, there are a few key differences between HTML and JSX:  Certain element attributes are different in JSX and HTML (class vs className) JSX must be transpiled into valid JavaScript, which React then uses to create DOM elements
answers.comments_html:
While they may look similar, there are a few key differences between HTML and JSX:

  • Certain element attributes are different in JSX and HTML (class vs className)
  • JSX must be transpiled into valid JavaScript, which React then uses to create DOM elements

answers.text: JSX is a valid form of JavaScript syntax.
answers.comments: On its own, JSX isn't valid JavaScript and is not part of the language. JSX must be transpiled into valid JavaScript using a tool like Babel.
answers.comments_html:
On its own, JSX isn't valid JavaScript and is not part of the language. JSX
must be transpiled into valid JavaScript using a tool like Babel.

answers.html: I don't know.

questions.question_text:
The following is a valid React component:

function App() {
  return (
    <Article />
    <Comment />
  );
}

answers.comments: Correct! A component can only return one top-level element. To return multiple top-level elements, you can use a Fragment.
answers.comments_html: Correct! A component can only return one top-level element. To return multiple top-level elements, you can use a Fragment.

answers.comments: A component can only return one element. We'd need to wrap the returned components in an enclosing tag or a Fragment like this to make it valid: function App() { return ( div Article / Comment / /div ); }
answers.comments_html:
A component can only return one element. We'd need to wrap the returned components in an enclosing tag or a Fragment like this to make it valid:

function App() {
  return (
    <div>
      <Article />
      <Comment />
    </div>
  );
}
